subject: Add support for sending NCSI command
commitMessage:
Add support for sending NCSI command

Provide a means to send an OEM command to an NIC via NCSI netlink.
This may be invoked from a systemd Unit file to configure NIC
behavior.

Some NICs provide OEM commands to influence their behavior, for
example maintaining full speed even when the host is down instead
of negotiating a lower speed for power.

Signed-off-by: Eddie James <eajames@linux.ibm.com>
Change-Id: Id920b618422e8fbfc51984fbf932045bfb5e56e6

Patch Set 1:

Eddie, Can you please explain what was the issue? and what command fixes the problem?
when do we use this infrastructure?

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Eddie, Can you please explain what was the issue? and what command fixes the problem?
> when do we use this infrastructure?

There is an issue with I210 chips using NCSI. If the host resets its network, BMC loses network as well. We need to be able to send an NCSI packet to the I210 to tell it to stay up despite host resets.
Once this is merged I will make a change with the necessary command in the ncsi-netlink service in meta-ibm.

Patch Set 7:

Hello,
I've just tried it on our Tioga Pass board and it does the right thing (to inhibit PHY reset) with
```
ncsi-netlink --package 0 --channel 0 --index 3 --oem-payload 00000157200001
```

However, I have to note that the UI differs from https://github.com/sammj/ncsi-netlink . With the C utility you can send and receive replies to arbitrary NC-SI commands, not just OEM, so the first byte to the "-o" option (short for "opcode") there is used to specify request type while with this proposed change it's hardcoded to 0x50 in C++. Thus not only the syntax differs (in C version strtoul(.., .., 0) is used, so each byte should be a separate argument with 0x prefix if you want hex) but a number of bytes to specify too. Is there a rationale for this especially given the C version got support long time ago, on Aug 24 2019?

Patch Set 7:

> 
> Hello,
> I've just tried it on our Tioga Pass board and it does the right thing (to inhibit PHY reset) with

> ncsi-netlink --package 0 --channel 0 --index 3 --oem-payload 00000157200001
> ```
> 
> However, I have to note that the UI differs from https://github.com/sammj/ncsi-netlink . With the C utility you can send and receive replies to arbitrary NC-SI commands, not just OEM, so the first byte to the "-o" option (short for "opcode") there is used to specify request type while with this proposed change it's hardcoded to 0x50 in C++. Thus not only the syntax differs (in C version strtoul(.., .., 0) is used, so each byte should be a separate argument with 0x prefix if you want hex) but a number of bytes to specify too. Is there a rationale for this especially given the C version got support long time ago, on Aug 24 2019?

I originally supported an opcode but code review suggested I only support the OEM command.

As for the data argument parsing, that sounds like a decent idea but I'd suggest that go in a separate commit now that we have three reviewers OK with the current setup.

Patch Set 7:

> I originally supported an opcode but code review suggested I only support the OEM command.

I see that's suggested by Milton D. Miller II with the rationale "So the kernel will accept any command packet, but will always force the command to be an OEM command when (assigning the sequence and) putting the packet on the wire." I'm not sure I'm following, the kernel code in question https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/latest/source/net/ncsi/ncsi-netlink.c#L456 doesn't seem to be limiting hdr->type in any way. Milton, can you please clarify?

> As for the data argument parsing, that sounds like a decent idea but I'd suggest that go in a separate commit now that we have three reviewers OK with the current setup.

Having two programs with the identical name and purpose use rather different syntax should better be avoided IMHO. I agree extending the parsing can be sent as a follow-up.

Huh, kernel commit f6edbf2d616435cda7823942c20005ce198e97c8 doesn't seem to be that nice. I think the real bug (handling non-OEM NCSI commands) should be fixed in ncsi_send_cmd_nl() by copying payload to the "bytes" buffer when command is not an OEM one. The initial support for sending commands introduced with 9771b8ccdfa6dcb1ac5128ca7fe8649f3092d392 doesn't mention any restrictions and the naming suggests it's really meant to be generic, not just for the OEM. Thanks for your swift response, Milton.

So the kernel will accept any command packet, but will always force the command to be an OEM command when (assigning the sequence and) putting the packet on the wire.

Is there a reason to pretend to send other commands vs just hard coding the command to be NCSI OEM command?
Ack
Done

I'm not familiar with C++ arg handling so will just observe that it seems like this for loop is not really intended to iterate because the body is checking for early exit and has special cases for the beginning?
Well it's iterating two at once so it has to check that it hasn't gone beyond the end of the string. Don't see the special cases for the beginning?
Done
can we make the above __u8 to go along with the __be16 and __be32 below?
Ack
Done
That's a reference, not an actual vector, so it must be initialized referring to something.
Seems it can be removed if we use the empty braces in initialization.

failed to parse ncsi genetlink message ?
(where did package come from?  packet?)

Do you handle "command sent, result was timeout waiting for ncsi response packet."?

The function above for the "info" callback refers to that as package - I can change it.

No, I think that's handled in the libnl layer?
The output of above would be a package list and then we run the loop for each package.

So this is dumping the response bytes on stdout but with other formatting around it.  Correct?  Should we have an option to save the response data?  or a comment for future enhancement.

Now sending only OEM commands and they always have a payload of at least the vendor id.
Done
I just notices most if not all of these long options have short forms but they are not listed in the help message.   Can be a seperate commit or folded in.

Not knowing C++ I looked up how stoi differs from the C functions that I know.  It appears to throw an excpetion if no coversion could be performed or if it exceeds the range of an int.

However, this still seems like weak verification:  Since the code has extracted to adjacent characters without regards to having an even number of characters, a user could pass a string with bytes separated by whitespace or an odd number of digits and still pass this parsing.

> a user could pass a string with bytes separated by whitespace 

What is the expectation here? We need to define the expectation of the string that bytes should be seprated with spaces or not.Can we document somewhere?
The code is expecting a string of hex digits, and I think that part is ok.   It should be documentted as you said, but also I am pointing out I think the validation of this assumption is weak.
I added a bit to make sure its an even number of digits at least.
Can we make it an error instead of trying to fix it?
Done

Payload invalid: specify two hex digits per byte

The bytes are not separatef so talking about zero padding is confusing.
Done, makes sense
Can you provide some background on why this change is needed?

Something along the lines of

Provide a means to send an OEM command to an NIC
via NCSI netlink.  This may be invoked from a 
systemd Unit file to configure NIC behavior.

Some NICs provide OEM commands to influence their behavior, for example maintaining full speed even when the host is down instead of negotiating a lower speed for power.
nit: '\0' instead of 0 to make the param intention more clear
Done

Can we change away from magic numbers, 16 in this case?
Or put a comment as to what the magic number is.

That "magic number" is the numerical base.  
That means that this conversion is hexadecimal

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexadecimal

That is the constant that is multiplied for each additional digit.
Do you still think this common value needs a constant define?
Do we need to spell out Hexadecimal in the error message saying specify two digits?

OK; I had thought it was a length.  Can a comment be added to clarify.

Thank you.
Use cstdint types not internal linux types.
Done
Don't store references directly as class members. Use a reference wrapper / pointer. Using a span would solve this problem too.
Done
Use `struct ethhdr` / `sizeof(ethhdr)` directly. 16 Wouldn't include the NCSI_PROTO, which I assume you don't need to specify / return here either.
sizeof(ethhdr) = 14 though. But I think we want to skip the NCSIPacketHeader here anyway, so I will use that size.
I imagine someone trying to capture the command line would prefer this on stderr.
Perhaps, but I prefer to use stderr for errors. There is a comment already about enhancement to save the response data, which would be a better way to capture it.

This entire loop could be way more succint with fmtlib:
fmt::print("{:02x}", fmt::join(s.begin(), s.end(), " "));
Done
I do not view this 8 as a significant magic number since it is only being used in output formatting.
Ack
Prefer stdplus::span<const unsigned char>
Done
Ack
